subsc: General industry and trade sector,Other domestic and international trade,Ports, waterways and shipping,Law and justice,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the program is
            rated partially satisfactory. Substantial progress was made
            in maritime liberalization, port and customs operations,
            telecommunications, the investment code, the business laws,
            the reduction of domestic arrears, and labor legislation.
            Little or no progress was achieved in the judicial system,
            tax administration, and the competition committee. Bank and
            Borrower performances were rated overall as satisfactory. To
            be successful, privates sector adjustment operations require
            the continued commitment of all stakeholders concerned. The
            Government failed to involve the private sector in a
            meaningful way during program implementation. The private
            sector felt alienated; its representatives had no say on the
            way conditions were met. While the commitment of the
            government to reform was strong overall, its commitment was
            weak in judicial and tax administration reform. Action plans
            or committees are no substitute for commitment. The
            so-called omnibus concept pioneered by this operation served
            well its purpose of providing funding at regular intervals
            to support the Government's reform program. Clear and
            measurable indicators of outcomes and impact should have
            been defined and agreed upon among all parties concerned for
            all components of the program. In areas where clear and
            monitorable indicators are difficult to establish, like the
            functioning of justice, an effort should have been made to
            measure the impact, with the private sector participating.
